instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD â€“ once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .
definitions.P5VS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS3_PGOOD? P5VS3_PGOOD indicates that the PP5V_S3 power rail is functioning properly..
definitions.P1V5S0_PGOOD: What is P1V5S0_PGOOD? P1V5S0_PGOOD is a signal that asserts itself when the PP1V5_S0 power rail turns on and works .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
Hello!

This board was clean or cleaned before I received it. Can't see any corrosion.

It does not charge the battery and it won't turn on from just power adapter.
If I install battery it goes to S0 state, but no CPU VCORE.
Fan is not running. GPU gets hot. 

Missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> so no <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>.

I checked <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and I have everything for <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, but it stays at 0V.

I checked:

<RESISTOR>R7968</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7966</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7964</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR>

and are all 0V.  However I'm sure I have <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> , <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> etc. 
However <SIGNAL>P1V5S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> etc. signals are 0V. 

I believe ISL fucked, but it looks clean. I checked sense resistors and traces and all looks ok.
I have green light, but with power adapter I don't have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. It's like 1.8V.  With battery is all ok. 
No short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Should I first fix the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> issue?

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
No use fixing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, it should run from battery. All PGOOD signals are tied together, so if one is pulling it down all will be low. Look at the diagram and measure all voltages that are required to generate ALL SYS PWRGD. 4 voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and 3 on <CHIP>U7960</CHIP> and all the PGOOD signals from regulators. 
Seeing as you are missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and at least one PGOOD signal I would say this was a liquid damaged machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
I checked the voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
These are measured  ok:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0_CPUDDR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
 
On pin 4 I have nothing. 0V

<CHIP>U7960</CHIP> is not on the board. Only different voltage is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> which is present.

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0</SIGNAL> is not present

Looks like I have to find out why I don't have anything on L7100.
No short. I checked <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and looks ok. I measured 3.3V on EN pin and I also have 5V on VCC and PVCC pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message: Dead <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> does happen. But I also have a 2915 here with this issue and I can't get it fixed. When flexing the board sometimes I get VCCSA. Good luck with this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message: Changed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> now it beeps for ram in both slots.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message: one beep or 3? Check power from <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> it is not included in the PGOOD circuit, so it can be missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
3 Beeps in both of the slots. I'm going to check <CHIP>U7300</CHIP>.

Edit: Unfortunately I've 1.5V there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
Yes, I'am. I also tried it with different modules. I checked the pins in the memory slots. Everything looks ok.
I checked the voltages at the memory slot and looks like I've everything there. Bad slot or CPU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message: I have no idea. First insert a memory slot tester to see if all contacts are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing CPU VCORE
threads.message:
I've to buy one. Never used it before.

Thank you!
